posts.title: 1 Pager / Spec Generator Wizard
posts.whatIBuilt: A webpage and a slackbot that walks users through some questions to help capture their idea and turn it into a formatted 1 pager or Product Spec
posts.howItWent: Really well! It was used by a couple of product managers on day 1. This was the first time I set up a slack bot. I also wanted to allow for 2 modes and use 2 platforms. That caused more challenges than I expected
posts.whatILearned: Keep it simple. While the slack bot functioned, the web page had some issues. I could have kept it to one mode, and worked through the challenges there first.
posts.biggestChallenge: Not getting too much scope in your first try.

posts.title: "Who Owns It" Slack Bot
posts.screenshot: screenshots/who owns it bot screenshot day-002.png
posts.whatIBuilt: A Python script that sends a formatted daily standup message to a Slack channel via webhook. Reads a config file to know what channel to post to and when, and uses a simple template so I just fill in what I did yesterday, today, and blockers.
posts.howItWent: The Slack webhook integration was easy. The scheduling part (getting it to run at 9am reliably) took more iteration than expected — ended up using a cron job on my Mac rather than trying to build scheduling into the script itself.
posts.whatILearned: Scope creep is real even with AI. I kept wanting to add features. Claude will happily build everything you ask for, so you have to be the one to say 'just do the core thing first.'
posts.biggestChallenge: Deciding what NOT to build — resisting the urge to add a full config UI.

posts.title: Screenshots Slack Bot
posts.whatIBuilt: An internal Slackbot that allows for users to add, search, provide tags and edit tags on images and screenshots of games we play and evaluate.
posts.howItWent: Started during lunch break, continued after hours during commander game, this time asking my team members to help test, which was great. Testing highlighted some small changes, and helped me think about actually making it for viable for a team to use.
posts.whatILearned: Trying to include more than “MVP” requirements, e.g. “use AI and NLP to support intent from users” as a choice rather than “Keep it simple and easy to build” led to… Issues with sharing my keys again! Claude is good about calling it out, I pasted an error that exposed my key. Maybe we all need some safety training? I got lost on json updates, file updates, key updates in json files, and errors started coming in. I asked claude, it helped, but it still assumes a lot. Be careful not get to get too far ahead of yourself. Testing with others is helpful! Sessions end and claude code can lose context, but seems to be aware of that. No problems to be seen at the moment, but something I’m guessing I should keep an eye on.
posts.biggestChallenge: I’ve enjoyed being at my computer and manually "allowing" each Claude action, get a sense of what’s going on. But now I want to “allow always” but I’m worried a bit about safety of doing that. Is there a way to know?

posts.title: This Website
posts.whatIBuilt: The very site you're looking at right now. A static blog/journal to document this entire challenge. Dark game-card aesthetic inspired by Marvel Snap, blog layout inspired by Framer. Pure HTML/CSS/JS with a JSON data file — no frameworks, no build step, deploys to GitHub Pages.
posts.howItWent: This was the easiest so far (partially because of what I've learned in previous days). Other than the prompt, no back and forth after the initial feedback I asked Claude to ask me too settle on scope. Claude finished, gave me the command prompts to run and admin password. Having to write up this info has been the most time consuming part.
posts.whatILearned: Getting comfortable with simple command line prompts is empowering. Telling Claude to suggest improvements or ask for clarity if needed seems to be really productive.
posts.biggestChallenge: Entering in the information for all of the projects to date. (Claude anticipated this, and asked me hjow many I had, to determine if there was a need for a data migration step.) Finding examples of what I wanted the to look like also took a few minutes.

posts.title: Immersive Card of the Day Website
posts.whatIBuilt: An immersive card of the day explorer tool where you can branch out into synergies, mechanics, sets, related commanders, budget or other interesting cards
posts.howItWent: Started off with asking Claude to find me "... of the day" websites to get some inspiration for how it would look and feel. While browsing, I found some fun examples that gave me the idea I went with, Magic cards and a Magic the gathering playmat immersive look and feel. Claude noticed a sentence I didn't finish in my second prompt, and asked me about it to make sure it had it clear before it continued on. It prompted me with a few options, the first option was correct.
posts.whatILearned: Rules based engine would be easier (and cheaper) than 1 powered by AI. I started with a local only version but told Claude I might want to push it live in the future. This is the first time I tried spending a bit more effort on "improving the look and feel" of a website or tool. I tried uploading images I took from examples I found on the web.
posts.biggestChallenge: After seeing the first version come so close to "immersive", going back and forth trying to get it to look good was harder than I thought. Not sure if it's a capability issue for claude, if my prompts are not great, need to play with with "improving look and feel"

posts.title: UI UX Prototyping Tool
posts.whatIBuilt: A UI / UX lightweight prototyping tool with only this prompt: Build a tool where users upload existing UI screenshots and describe a feature idea, and after providing some options for the user to select from, build a prototype they can browse interactively.
posts.howItWent: One of the easiest so far, after getitng set up. Started using Claude CLI on windows! Had to get help from a programmer to get set up. Using Powershell (run as administrator!). Set up bash (hard on windows for some reason?) Some issues with my PATH? All new things, and having a programmer ride shotgun was great, but
posts.whatILearned:
Knowing how to get my API key from a previous project was critical! Using Claude CLI means a bit less of an easy back and forth, so there wasn't an 

I typically write "please" and "thank you" in most of my prompts and responses. The programmer who helped me get set up explained that it's better to be direct, clear and remove extra things. They can just get in the way of the job getting done.
posts.biggestChallenge: Getting the UI to actually match what I uploaded. There are other tools out there that can do generic prototyping and mocks, I was hoping to use one that could leverage our existing UI.
